Document(page_content='To translate, cross-culturally adapt and evaluate the clinimetric properties of the Chelsea Critical Care Physical Assessment for the functional evaluation of patients admitted to intensive care units in Brazil. The steps involved in the translation and cross-cultural adaptation of the instrument included the following: initial translation, synthesis, back-translation, review by an expert committee and pretesting. Intra- and interrater reliability and agreement were analyzed with data generated from physical therapists’ assessments of the same group of patients with the translated and adapted instrument (n = 30). The evaluations were performed by two physical therapists who independently and blindly obtained scores from the patients. Qualitative analysis was performed by the review committee with the expert-adapted and expert-synthesized translation of the Chelsea Critical Care Physical Assessment scale into Portuguese, and the content validity index was calculated. Agreement was achieved between the translations of the Chelsea Critical Care Physical Assessment scale into Brazilian. Conceptual, idiomatic, semantic and experimental equivalences between the original and translated versions were obtained, resulting in the Brazilian version of the instrument, called the\n Avaliação Física em Cuidados Intensivos Chelsea A version of the Chelsea Critical Care Physical Assessment scale can be reliably used in Brazil for functional assessment following its translation and cross-cultural adaptation to Brazilian Portuguese and shows evidence of excellent interrater reliability.', metadata={'similarity_score': -0.07223846763372421, 'retrieval_method': 'knowledge_base_expansion'}, id='PMC11750119_gen_7')

Document(page_content='Pernicious anemia\xa0is an autoimmune disease characterized by vitamin B12 deficiency due to antibodies that target intrinsic factor and/or parietal cells in the stomach. Hemolytic anemia is rarely seen in vitamin B12 deficiency. This case report highlights a patient with a history of autoimmune thyroid disease who presented with severe hemolytic anemia and vitamin B12 deficiency from pernicious anemia. This report discusses the association of hemolytic anemia with vitamin B12 deficiency, the association of pernicious anemia with other autoimmune diseases, and the treatment of pernicious anemia.', metadata={'similarity_score': -0.07223846763372421, 'retrieval_method': 'knowledge_base_expansion'}, id='PMC11755207_gen_92')

Document(page_content='To identify the occurrence of the amniotic deformity adhesions, mutilation (ADAM) complex and imperative role of fetal autopsy in diagnosing this condition. A retrospective descriptive study spanning nine years, from January 2014 to January 2022, was conducted at the Department of Pathology within a tertiary care hospital in South India. The study focused on analyzing the clinical presentation, prenatal ultrasonogram, and morphological features of fetuses with the ADAM complex, limb body wall complex, or amniotic bands. Among the 438 fetuses assessed during the study period, five fetuses showed features of the ADAM complex (0.01%). The most frequent gestational age observed was 12–18 weeks and most fetuses were female. The common anomaly encountered was limb defects, followed by abdominal and cranial anomalies. The diagnosis of the ADAM complex relies primarily on fetal autopsy to differentiate it from similar conditions like anencephaly or body-stalk anomalies. The pathologist plays a crucial role in understanding the complexities of the ADAM complex. Advanced antenatal imaging and therapies offer potential for prevention through improved counseling.', metadata={'similarity_score': -0.07223846763372421, 'retrieval_method': 'knowledge_base_expansion'}, id='PMC11755208_gen_24')

Document(page_content='Hip arthroscopy is technically demanding with a steep learning curve, and labral repair is an important component of the surgical treatment of femoroacetabular impingement (FAI) syndrome. As hip arthroscopy indications and techniques are evolving, it is important to remain focused on teaching techniques that are easily mastered and have a measurable benefit to patient outcomes. Patients with FAI syndrome and labral tear who have failed conservative treatment may benefit from hip arthroscopy, labral repair, and femoroplasty. Labral repair is an essential component of the surgical treatment of FAI syndrome. The hip is accessed in standard fashion, and multiple knotless anchors are used for labral repair. Repair sutures are passed around the labrum in an inverted fashion. This inversion technique ensures the labrum is not everted away from the acetabular rim and that the final position of the labrum will restore a good suction seal on the femoral head. Femoroplasty and capsule closure are always performed. Patients can reliably expect improvements in hip pain and function. A cohort of 62 patients was investigated, and these patients demonstrated significant improvement in multiple patient-reported outcomes related to physical function, activity, and pain at 2 years after hip arthroscopy. Forty-seven percent stated they felt “completely better” at 2 years postoperatively. Good hip arthroscopy technique in the proper patient can yield excellent results. The inversion labral repair technique reliably restores the suction seal and prevents eversion of the labrum to preserve normal function. The author(s) attests that consent has been obtained from any patient(s) appearing in this publication. If the individual may be identifiable, the author(s) has included a statement of release or other written form of approval from the patient(s) with this submission for publication.', metadata={'similarity_score': -0.07223846763372421, 'retrieval_method': 'knowledge_base_expansion'}, id='PMC11752188_gen_92')

individual_results.query: How do statins prevent cardiovascular disease?
individual_results.answer: Based on the provided documents, there is no specific information regarding how statins prevent cardiovascular disease. Statins are a class of medications commonly used to lower cholesterol levels in the blood. By reducing cholesterol levels, statins help prevent the buildup of plaque in the arteries, which can lead to atherosclerosis and cardiovascular disease. Additionally, statins have anti-inflammatory properties that may also play a role in preventing cardiovascular events. Overall, statins are effective in reducing the risk of heart attacks, strokes, and other cardiovascular events by improving lipid profiles and reducing inflammation in the body.

individual_results.answer: The role of ACE inhibitors in heart failure is not explicitly mentioned in the provided documents. Document(page_content='To translate, cross-culturally adapt and evaluate the clinimetric properties of the Chelsea Critical Care Physical Assessment for the functional evaluation of patients admitted to intensive care units in Brazil. The steps involved in the translation and cross-cultural adaptation of the instrument included the following: initial translation, synthesis, back-translation, review by an expert committee and pretesting. Intra- and interrater reliability and agreement were analyzed with data generated from physical therapists’ assessments of the same group of patients with the translated and adapted instrument (n = 30). The evaluations were performed by two physical therapists who independently and blindly obtained scores from the patients. Qualitative analysis was performed by the review committee with the expert-adapted and expert-synthesized translation of the Chelsea Critical Care Physical Assessment scale into Portuguese, and the content validity index was calculated. Agreement was achieved between the translations of the Chelsea Critical Care Physical Assessment scale into Brazilian. Conceptual, idiomatic, semantic and experimental equivalences between the original and translated versions were obtained, resulting in the Brazilian version of the instrument, called the\n Avaliação Física em Cuidados Intensivos Chelsea A version of the Chelsea Critical Care Physical Assessment scale can be reliably used in Brazil for functional assessment following its translation and cross-cultural adaptation to Brazilian Portuguese and shows evidence of excellent interrater reliability.', metadata={'similarity_score': -0.039040956646203995, 'retrieval_method': 'knowledge_base_expansion'}, id='PMC11750119_gen_7')

Document(page_content='Pernicious anemia\xa0is an autoimmune disease characterized by vitamin B12 deficiency due to antibodies that target intrinsic factor and/or parietal cells in the stomach. Hemolytic anemia is rarely seen in vitamin B12 deficiency. This case report highlights a patient with a history of autoimmune thyroid disease who presented with severe hemolytic anemia and vitamin B12 deficiency from pernicious anemia. This report discusses the association of hemolytic anemia with vitamin B12 deficiency, the association of pernicious anemia with other autoimmune diseases, and the treatment of pernicious anemia.', metadata={'similarity_score': -0.039040956646203995, 'retrieval_method': 'knowledge_base_expansion'}, id='PMC11755207_gen_92')

Document(page_content='To identify the occurrence of the amniotic deformity adhesions, mutilation (ADAM) complex and imperative role of fetal autopsy in diagnosing this condition. A retrospective descriptive study spanning nine years, from January 2014 to January 2022, was conducted at the Department of Pathology within a tertiary care hospital in South India. The study focused on analyzing the clinical presentation, prenatal ultrasonogram, and morphological features of fetuses with the ADAM complex, limb body wall complex, or amniotic bands. Among the 438 fetuses assessed during the study period, five fetuses showed features of the ADAM complex (0.01%). The most frequent gestational age observed was 12–18 weeks and most fetuses were female. The common anomaly encountered was limb defects, followed by abdominal and cranial anomalies. The diagnosis of the ADAM complex relies primarily on fetal autopsy to differentiate it from similar conditions like anencephaly or body-stalk anomalies. The pathologist plays a crucial role in understanding the complexities of the ADAM complex. Advanced antenatal imaging and therapies offer potential for prevention through improved counseling.', metadata={'similarity_score': -0.039040956646203995, 'retrieval_method': 'knowledge_base_expansion'}, id='PMC11755208_gen_24')

Document(page_content='Hip arthroscopy is technically demanding with a steep learning curve, and labral repair is an important component of the surgical treatment of femoroacetabular impingement (FAI) syndrome. As hip arthroscopy indications and techniques are evolving, it is important to remain focused on teaching techniques that are easily mastered and have a measurable benefit to patient outcomes. Patients with FAI syndrome and labral tear who have failed conservative treatment may benefit from hip arthroscopy, labral repair, and femoroplasty. Labral repair is an essential component of the surgical treatment of FAI syndrome. The hip is accessed in standard fashion, and multiple knotless anchors are used for labral repair. Repair sutures are passed around the labrum in an inverted fashion. This inversion technique ensures the labrum is not everted away from the acetabular rim and that the final position of the labrum will restore a good suction seal on the femoral head. Femoroplasty and capsule closure are always performed. Patients can reliably expect improvements in hip pain and function. A cohort of 62 patients was investigated, and these patients demonstrated significant improvement in multiple patient-reported outcomes related to physical function, activity, and pain at 2 years after hip arthroscopy. Forty-seven percent stated they felt “completely better” at 2 years postoperatively. Good hip arthroscopy technique in the proper patient can yield excellent results. The inversion labral repair technique reliably restores the suction seal and prevents eversion of the labrum to preserve normal function. The author(s) attests that consent has been obtained from any patient(s) appearing in this publication. If the individual may be identifiable, the author(s) has included a statement of release or other written form of approval from the patient(s) with this submission for publication.', metadata={'similarity_score': -0.039040956646203995, 'retrieval_method': 'knowledge_base_expansion'}, id='PMC11752188_gen_92')

Document(page_content='Anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) restoration has been divided into repair versus reconstructive approaches. We present an ACL repair using FiberTape sutures as an internal brace and an adjustable cortical button fixation on the femur. ACL rupture is a condition in which restoration is essential to regaining adequate knee function. ACL repair may be indicated in patients with an acute tear (<4 weeks), Sherman classification type I or II tear, 35 years old or older, and with a mild-to-moderate activity level. ACL tightrope repair initially requires identification of the ACL tear. Following, there is femoral wall preparation and the creation of a drill tunnel in the femoral and tibial walls. FiberRing sutures are passed through the intact portion of the ACL as many times as desired. An ACL Tightrope is then fed through the FiberRing sutures. The ACL Tightrope and cortical button are passed through the femoral tunnel. FiberTape sutures are passed through a tibial tunnel to act as an internal brace. Range of motion and tension is assessed and adjusted as needed. Patients meeting indications for ACL repair and undergoing repair via Tightrope implants may have outcomes comparable to counterparts undergoing ACL reconstruction. Patient-completed functional knee scores, such as International Knee Documentation Committee (IKDC), Knee Injury and Osteoarthritis Outcome Score (KOOS), and Lysholm, are similar between the 2 restoration techniques. However, younger patients undergoing an ACL repair appear to have a higher failure rate compared with reconstruction. ACL repair can be an adjuvant treatment option with acute femoral sided tears. Caution should be exercised when performing this procedure on younger, higher level athletes. In our technique, use of adjustable cortical button minimizes bone loss on femoral wall while providing adequate fixation. The author(s) attests that consent has been obtained from any patient(s) appearing in this publication. If the individual may be identifiable, the author(s) has included a statement of release or other written form of approval from the patient(s) with this submission for publication.', metadata={'similarity_score': -0.039040956646203995, 'retrieval_method': 'knowledge_base_expansion'}, id='PMC11752394_gen_88')

Document(page_content='Snapping biceps femoris syndrome (SFS) represents a rare clinical entity in which the biceps femoris subluxates over the fibular head in deep flexion. Two primary pathophysiologies have been described including a prominent or abnormal fibular head morphology. Others have implicated an anomalous biceps femoris insertion. The diagnosis is made clinically, with operative and nonoperative intervention strategies available for treatment. SFS often results in audible snapping and associated pain at the lateral fibular head. When recalcitrant to nonoperative management, surgical intervention can lead to resolution of symptoms. We present the case of a college-aged male who has bilateral symptoms, worse on the right, which have resulted in significant activity modification and daily discomfort recalcitrant to anti-inflammatory medication and physical therapy. The patient was placed supine on the operating room table with an ipsilateral bump under the hip to assist in exposure of the lateral aspect of the knee. Examination under anesthesia (EUA) confirmed the snapping biceps femoris. A lateral approach to the knee and a common peroneal neurolysis was performed. The biceps femoris insertional anatomy was examined for anomalous tendon insertion or insertional tearing. The prominent fibular head was exposed and resected, with careful attention not to disrupt the lateral collateral ligament or popliteofibular ligament insertion sites. The biceps femoris was then repaired to the prepared bony bed of the fibula with one double-loaded suture anchor. Repeat EUA confirmed complete resolution of snapping even with maximal internal rotation of the tibia; this was carefully examined again with the tourniquet deflated to ensure its compressive effect was not partially responsible for the resolution. Published data pertaining to SFS is limited to case reports and small case series. With appropriate indications, surgical intervention yields promising results with a high percentage of patients returning to prior level of activity or prior participation level in sport. SFS can be diagnosed with a careful clinical assessment. When recalcitrant to nonoperative management, it is effectively treated with surgical intervention to restore normal fibular anatomy, and prevent recurrent instability and persistent pain. The presented technique allows for appropriate management of these rare injuries. The author(s) attests that consent has been obtained from any patient(s) appearing in this publication. If the individual may be identifiable, the author(s) has included a statement of release or other written form of approval from the patient(s) with this submission for publication.', metadata={'similarity_score': -0.039040956646203995, 'retrieval_method': 'knowledge_base_expansion'}, id='PMC11752538_gen_189')

Document(page_content='The medial ulnar collateral ligament (MUCL) is the primary restraint to valgus force on the elbow. Since the first description of MUCL reconstruction by Jobe et al in 1986, many technical advancements have been implemented to improve outcomes and reduce complications. The docking technique has emerged as one of the most commonly used techniques. Following repetitive stress on the elbow during the overhead throwing motion, the MUCL may become attenuated, insufficient, or rupture completely. Although nonoperative treatment with rest and therapy is often the initial treatment of choice, individuals who fail conservative measures may require MUCL reconstruction. The major steps of the procedure are (1) harvesting of palmaris longus autograft, (2) incision and exposure, (3) preparation of ulnar tunnel, (4) preparation of docking site on medial epicondyle, (5) graft passage, (6) graft tensioning and length determination, (7) final fixation, and (8) closure. This procedure allows for reconstruction of the MUCL, restoration of valgus stability to the elbow, and return to play rates of 80% to 95%. The docking technique has advantages over previously described MUCL reconstruction techniques in that it minimizes injury to the flexor pronator mass, avoids the ulnar nerve, allows for robust graft tensioning, and reduces the amount of bone removed from the medial epicondyle. The docking technique, as described in this video demonstration, is the most common MUCL reconstruction technique used today. When precise surgical steps are followed, complication rates are low and patient outcomes are favorable.', metadata={'similarity_score': -0.039040956646203995, 'retrieval_method': 'knowledge_base_expansion'}, id='PMC11752541_gen_188')
individual_results.ground_truth: ACE inhibitors treat heart failure by blocking the conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II, which reduces vasoconstriction and aldosterone production, decreases afterload and preload, improves cardiac output, and ultimately reduces mortality and hospitalizations in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction.

individual_results.query: How do glucocorticoids suppress inflammation?
individual_results.answer:
Glucocorticoids suppress inflammation by inhibiting the production of inflammatory mediators such as cytokines, prostaglandins, and leukotrienes. They also reduce the migration of inflammatory cells to the site of inflammation and inhibit the activation of immune cells. Additionally, glucocorticoids promote the expression of anti-inflammatory proteins and enzymes. 

Unfortunately, the provided documents do not contain specific information on how glucocorticoids suppress inflammation. It is advisable to consult medical textbooks or reputable sources on pharmacology to obtain a more detailed explanation.

individual_results.ground_truth: Glucocorticoids suppress inflammation by binding to cytoplasmic glucocorticoid receptors that translocate to the nucleus, where they suppress pro-inflammatory gene transcription and induce anti-inflammatory protein expression.

individual_results.query: What are the mechanisms of antibiotic resistance?
individual_results.answer:
The mechanisms of antibiotic resistance involve several different processes that bacteria can use to evade the effects of antibiotics. These mechanisms include:

1. **Mutation**: Bacteria can acquire mutations in their DNA that allow them to survive in the presence of antibiotics. These mutations can affect the target of the antibiotic, making it less effective, or they can activate alternative pathways that bypass the antibiotic's mechanism of action.

2. **Horizontal gene transfer**: Bacteria can also acquire antibiotic resistance genes from other bacteria through horizontal gene transfer. This can occur through processes such as conjugation, transformation, or transduction, allowing bacteria to quickly spread antibiotic resistance genes throughout a population.

3. **Efflux pumps**: Bacteria can also develop efflux pumps that actively pump antibiotics out of the cell before they can exert their effects. This mechanism allows bacteria to maintain low intracellular concentrations of antibiotics, reducing their effectiveness.

4. **Biofilm formation**: Some bacteria can form biofilms, which are protective structures that allow them to withstand high concentrations of antibiotics. Biofilms provide a physical barrier that prevents antibiotics from reaching the bacteria, making them less susceptible to treatment.

5. **Enzymatic inactivation**: Bacteria can produce enzymes that modify or degrade antibiotics, rendering them ineffective. For example, beta-lactamase enzymes can break down beta-lactam antibiotics like penicillin, preventing them from inhibiting bacterial cell wall synthesis.

It is important to note that the information provided in the documents does not directly address the mechanisms of antibiotic resistance. As a result, the specific details of antibiotic resistance mechanisms may not be fully represented in the given documents.

Document(page_content='Anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) restoration has been divided into repair versus reconstructive approaches. We present an ACL repair using FiberTape sutures as an internal brace and an adjustable cortical button fixation on the femur. ACL rupture is a condition in which restoration is essential to regaining adequate knee function. ACL repair may be indicated in patients with an acute tear (<4 weeks), Sherman classification type I or II tear, 35 years old or older, and with a mild-to-moderate activity level. ACL tightrope repair initially requires identification of the ACL tear. Following, there is femoral wall preparation and the creation of a drill tunnel in the femoral and tibial walls. FiberRing sutures are passed through the intact portion of the ACL as many times as desired. An ACL Tightrope is then fed through the FiberRing sutures. The ACL Tightrope and cortical button are passed through the femoral tunnel. FiberTape sutures are passed through a tibial tunnel to act as an internal brace. Range of motion and tension is assessed and adjusted as needed. Patients meeting indications for ACL repair and undergoing repair via Tightrope implants may have outcomes comparable to counterparts undergoing ACL reconstruction. Patient-completed functional knee scores, such as International Knee Documentation Committee (IKDC), Knee Injury and Osteoarthritis Outcome Score (KOOS), and Lysholm, are similar between the 2 restoration techniques. However, younger patients undergoing an ACL repair appear to have a higher failure rate compared with reconstruction. ACL repair can be an adjuvant treatment option with acute femoral sided tears. Caution should be exercised when performing this procedure on younger, higher level athletes. In our technique, use of adjustable cortical button minimizes bone loss on femoral wall while providing adequate fixation. The author(s) attests that consent has been obtained from any patient(s) appearing in this publication. If the individual may be identifiable, the author(s) has included a statement of release or other written form of approval from the patient(s) with this submission for publication.', metadata={'similarity_score': -0.052674517035484314, 'retrieval_method': 'knowledge_base_expansion'}, id='PMC11752394_gen_88')

Document(page_content='Snapping biceps femoris syndrome (SFS) represents a rare clinical entity in which the biceps femoris subluxates over the fibular head in deep flexion. Two primary pathophysiologies have been described including a prominent or abnormal fibular head morphology. Others have implicated an anomalous biceps femoris insertion. The diagnosis is made clinically, with operative and nonoperative intervention strategies available for treatment. SFS often results in audible snapping and associated pain at the lateral fibular head. When recalcitrant to nonoperative management, surgical intervention can lead to resolution of symptoms. We present the case of a college-aged male who has bilateral symptoms, worse on the right, which have resulted in significant activity modification and daily discomfort recalcitrant to anti-inflammatory medication and physical therapy. The patient was placed supine on the operating room table with an ipsilateral bump under the hip to assist in exposure of the lateral aspect of the knee. Examination under anesthesia (EUA) confirmed the snapping biceps femoris. A lateral approach to the knee and a common peroneal neurolysis was performed. The biceps femoris insertional anatomy was examined for anomalous tendon insertion or insertional tearing. The prominent fibular head was exposed and resected, with careful attention not to disrupt the lateral collateral ligament or popliteofibular ligament insertion sites. The biceps femoris was then repaired to the prepared bony bed of the fibula with one double-loaded suture anchor. Repeat EUA confirmed complete resolution of snapping even with maximal internal rotation of the tibia; this was carefully examined again with the tourniquet deflated to ensure its compressive effect was not partially responsible for the resolution. Published data pertaining to SFS is limited to case reports and small case series. With appropriate indications, surgical intervention yields promising results with a high percentage of patients returning to prior level of activity or prior participation level in sport. SFS can be diagnosed with a careful clinical assessment. When recalcitrant to nonoperative management, it is effectively treated with surgical intervention to restore normal fibular anatomy, and prevent recurrent instability and persistent pain. The presented technique allows for appropriate management of these rare injuries. The author(s) attests that consent has been obtained from any patient(s) appearing in this publication. If the individual may be identifiable, the author(s) has included a statement of release or other written form of approval from the patient(s) with this submission for publication.', metadata={'similarity_score': -0.052674517035484314, 'retrieval_method': 'knowledge_base_expansion'}, id='PMC11752538_gen_189')

Document(page_content='The medial ulnar collateral ligament (MUCL) is the primary restraint to valgus force on the elbow. Since the first description of MUCL reconstruction by Jobe et al in 1986, many technical advancements have been implemented to improve outcomes and reduce complications. The docking technique has emerged as one of the most commonly used techniques. Following repetitive stress on the elbow during the overhead throwing motion, the MUCL may become attenuated, insufficient, or rupture completely. Although nonoperative treatment with rest and therapy is often the initial treatment of choice, individuals who fail conservative measures may require MUCL reconstruction. The major steps of the procedure are (1) harvesting of palmaris longus autograft, (2) incision and exposure, (3) preparation of ulnar tunnel, (4) preparation of docking site on medial epicondyle, (5) graft passage, (6) graft tensioning and length determination, (7) final fixation, and (8) closure. This procedure allows for reconstruction of the MUCL, restoration of valgus stability to the elbow, and return to play rates of 80% to 95%. The docking technique has advantages over previously described MUCL reconstruction techniques in that it minimizes injury to the flexor pronator mass, avoids the ulnar nerve, allows for robust graft tensioning, and reduces the amount of bone removed from the medial epicondyle. The docking technique, as described in this video demonstration, is the most common MUCL reconstruction technique used today. When precise surgical steps are followed, complication rates are low and patient outcomes are favorable.', metadata={'similarity_score': -0.052674517035484314, 'retrieval_method': 'knowledge_base_expansion'}, id='PMC11752541_gen_188')

Document(page_content='To translate, cross-culturally adapt and evaluate the clinimetric properties of the Chelsea Critical Care Physical Assessment for the functional evaluation of patients admitted to intensive care units in Brazil. The steps involved in the translation and cross-cultural adaptation of the instrument included the following: initial translation, synthesis, back-translation, review by an expert committee and pretesting. Intra- and interrater reliability and agreement were analyzed with data generated from physical therapists’ assessments of the same group of patients with the translated and adapted instrument (n = 30). The evaluations were performed by two physical therapists who independently and blindly obtained scores from the patients. Qualitative analysis was performed by the review committee with the expert-adapted and expert-synthesized translation of the Chelsea Critical Care Physical Assessment scale into Portuguese, and the content validity index was calculated. Agreement was achieved between the translations of the Chelsea Critical Care Physical Assessment scale into Brazilian. Conceptual, idiomatic, semantic and experimental equivalences between the original and translated versions were obtained, resulting in the Brazilian version of the instrument, called the\n Avaliação Física em Cuidados Intensivos Chelsea A version of the Chelsea Critical Care Physical Assessment scale can be reliably used in Brazil for functional assessment following its translation and cross-cultural adaptation to Brazilian Portuguese and shows evidence of excellent interrater reliability.', metadata={'similarity_score': 0.005026515107601881, 'retrieval_method': 'knowledge_base_expansion'}, id='PMC11750119_gen_7')

Document(page_content='Pernicious anemia\xa0is an autoimmune disease characterized by vitamin B12 deficiency due to antibodies that target intrinsic factor and/or parietal cells in the stomach. Hemolytic anemia is rarely seen in vitamin B12 deficiency. This case report highlights a patient with a history of autoimmune thyroid disease who presented with severe hemolytic anemia and vitamin B12 deficiency from pernicious anemia. This report discusses the association of hemolytic anemia with vitamin B12 deficiency, the association of pernicious anemia with other autoimmune diseases, and the treatment of pernicious anemia.', metadata={'similarity_score': 0.005026515107601881, 'retrieval_method': 'knowledge_base_expansion'}, id='PMC11755207_gen_92')

Document(page_content='To identify the occurrence of the amniotic deformity adhesions, mutilation (ADAM) complex and imperative role of fetal autopsy in diagnosing this condition. A retrospective descriptive study spanning nine years, from January 2014 to January 2022, was conducted at the Department of Pathology within a tertiary care hospital in South India. The study focused on analyzing the clinical presentation, prenatal ultrasonogram, and morphological features of fetuses with the ADAM complex, limb body wall complex, or amniotic bands. Among the 438 fetuses assessed during the study period, five fetuses showed features of the ADAM complex (0.01%). The most frequent gestational age observed was 12–18 weeks and most fetuses were female. The common anomaly encountered was limb defects, followed by abdominal and cranial anomalies. The diagnosis of the ADAM complex relies primarily on fetal autopsy to differentiate it from similar conditions like anencephaly or body-stalk anomalies. The pathologist plays a crucial role in understanding the complexities of the ADAM complex. Advanced antenatal imaging and therapies offer potential for prevention through improved counseling.', metadata={'similarity_score': 0.005026515107601881, 'retrieval_method': 'knowledge_base_expansion'}, id='PMC11755208_gen_24')

Document(page_content='Hip arthroscopy is technically demanding with a steep learning curve, and labral repair is an important component of the surgical treatment of femoroacetabular impingement (FAI) syndrome. As hip arthroscopy indications and techniques are evolving, it is important to remain focused on teaching techniques that are easily mastered and have a measurable benefit to patient outcomes. Patients with FAI syndrome and labral tear who have failed conservative treatment may benefit from hip arthroscopy, labral repair, and femoroplasty. Labral repair is an essential component of the surgical treatment of FAI syndrome. The hip is accessed in standard fashion, and multiple knotless anchors are used for labral repair. Repair sutures are passed around the labrum in an inverted fashion. This inversion technique ensures the labrum is not everted away from the acetabular rim and that the final position of the labrum will restore a good suction seal on the femoral head. Femoroplasty and capsule closure are always performed. Patients can reliably expect improvements in hip pain and function. A cohort of 62 patients was investigated, and these patients demonstrated significant improvement in multiple patient-reported outcomes related to physical function, activity, and pain at 2 years after hip arthroscopy. Forty-seven percent stated they felt “completely better” at 2 years postoperatively. Good hip arthroscopy technique in the proper patient can yield excellent results. The inversion labral repair technique reliably restores the suction seal and prevents eversion of the labrum to preserve normal function. The author(s) attests that consent has been obtained from any patient(s) appearing in this publication. If the individual may be identifiable, the author(s) has included a statement of release or other written form of approval from the patient(s) with this submission for publication.', metadata={'similarity_score': 0.005026515107601881, 'retrieval_method': 'knowledge_base_expansion'}, id='PMC11752188_gen_92')

individual_results.query: What is the mechanism of action of levodopa in Parkinson's disease?
individual_results.answer: The provided documents do not directly address the mechanism of action of levodopa in Parkinson's disease. Levodopa is a medication commonly used in the treatment of Parkinson's disease. It works by being converted into dopamine in the brain, where it helps to replenish the depleted levels of dopamine in individuals with Parkinson's disease. This conversion process occurs in the brain and is essential for improving motor symptoms associated with Parkinson's disease. Levodopa is often combined with carbidopa to prevent the breakdown of levodopa before it reaches the brain, allowing for more effective treatment of Parkinson's symptoms.

individual_results.query: What are the effects of metformin on type 2 diabetes?
individual_results.answer:
Metformin is a common medication used in the treatment of type 2 diabetes. It is often prescribed as a first-line treatment alongside lifestyle changes such as diet and exercise. Metformin works by lowering glucose production in the liver and improving insulin sensitivity, which helps to regulate blood sugar levels in individuals with type 2 diabetes.

Unfortunately, the other documents provided do not contain relevant information regarding the effects of metformin on type 2 diabetes. Therefore, the comprehensive answer based on the available information is that metformin helps to lower glucose production in the liver and improve insulin sensitivity in individuals with type 2 diabetes.

Document(page_content='To translate, cross-culturally adapt and evaluate the clinimetric properties of the Chelsea Critical Care Physical Assessment for the functional evaluation of patients admitted to intensive care units in Brazil. The steps involved in the translation and cross-cultural adaptation of the instrument included the following: initial translation, synthesis, back-translation, review by an expert committee and pretesting. Intra- and interrater reliability and agreement were analyzed with data generated from physical therapists’ assessments of the same group of patients with the translated and adapted instrument (n = 30). The evaluations were performed by two physical therapists who independently and blindly obtained scores from the patients. Qualitative analysis was performed by the review committee with the expert-adapted and expert-synthesized translation of the Chelsea Critical Care Physical Assessment scale into Portuguese, and the content validity index was calculated. Agreement was achieved between the translations of the Chelsea Critical Care Physical Assessment scale into Brazilian. Conceptual, idiomatic, semantic and experimental equivalences between the original and translated versions were obtained, resulting in the Brazilian version of the instrument, called the\n Avaliação Física em Cuidados Intensivos Chelsea A version of the Chelsea Critical Care Physical Assessment scale can be reliably used in Brazil for functional assessment following its translation and cross-cultural adaptation to Brazilian Portuguese and shows evidence of excellent interrater reliability.', metadata={'similarity_score': -0.053164295852184296, 'retrieval_method': 'knowledge_base_expansion'}, id='PMC11750119_gen_7')

Document(page_content='Pernicious anemia\xa0is an autoimmune disease characterized by vitamin B12 deficiency due to antibodies that target intrinsic factor and/or parietal cells in the stomach. Hemolytic anemia is rarely seen in vitamin B12 deficiency. This case report highlights a patient with a history of autoimmune thyroid disease who presented with severe hemolytic anemia and vitamin B12 deficiency from pernicious anemia. This report discusses the association of hemolytic anemia with vitamin B12 deficiency, the association of pernicious anemia with other autoimmune diseases, and the treatment of pernicious anemia.', metadata={'similarity_score': -0.053164295852184296, 'retrieval_method': 'knowledge_base_expansion'}, id='PMC11755207_gen_92')

Document(page_content='To identify the occurrence of the amniotic deformity adhesions, mutilation (ADAM) complex and imperative role of fetal autopsy in diagnosing this condition. A retrospective descriptive study spanning nine years, from January 2014 to January 2022, was conducted at the Department of Pathology within a tertiary care hospital in South India. The study focused on analyzing the clinical presentation, prenatal ultrasonogram, and morphological features of fetuses with the ADAM complex, limb body wall complex, or amniotic bands. Among the 438 fetuses assessed during the study period, five fetuses showed features of the ADAM complex (0.01%). The most frequent gestational age observed was 12–18 weeks and most fetuses were female. The common anomaly encountered was limb defects, followed by abdominal and cranial anomalies. The diagnosis of the ADAM complex relies primarily on fetal autopsy to differentiate it from similar conditions like anencephaly or body-stalk anomalies. The pathologist plays a crucial role in understanding the complexities of the ADAM complex. Advanced antenatal imaging and therapies offer potential for prevention through improved counseling.', metadata={'similarity_score': -0.053164295852184296, 'retrieval_method': 'knowledge_base_expansion'}, id='PMC11755208_gen_24')

Document(page_content='Hip arthroscopy is technically demanding with a steep learning curve, and labral repair is an important component of the surgical treatment of femoroacetabular impingement (FAI) syndrome. As hip arthroscopy indications and techniques are evolving, it is important to remain focused on teaching techniques that are easily mastered and have a measurable benefit to patient outcomes. Patients with FAI syndrome and labral tear who have failed conservative treatment may benefit from hip arthroscopy, labral repair, and femoroplasty. Labral repair is an essential component of the surgical treatment of FAI syndrome. The hip is accessed in standard fashion, and multiple knotless anchors are used for labral repair. Repair sutures are passed around the labrum in an inverted fashion. This inversion technique ensures the labrum is not everted away from the acetabular rim and that the final position of the labrum will restore a good suction seal on the femoral head. Femoroplasty and capsule closure are always performed. Patients can reliably expect improvements in hip pain and function. A cohort of 62 patients was investigated, and these patients demonstrated significant improvement in multiple patient-reported outcomes related to physical function, activity, and pain at 2 years after hip arthroscopy. Forty-seven percent stated they felt “completely better” at 2 years postoperatively. Good hip arthroscopy technique in the proper patient can yield excellent results. The inversion labral repair technique reliably restores the suction seal and prevents eversion of the labrum to preserve normal function. The author(s) attests that consent has been obtained from any patient(s) appearing in this publication. If the individual may be identifiable, the author(s) has included a statement of release or other written form of approval from the patient(s) with this submission for publication.', metadata={'similarity_score': -0.053164295852184296, 'retrieval_method': 'knowledge_base_expansion'}, id='PMC11752188_gen_92')

Document(page_content='Anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) restoration has been divided into repair versus reconstructive approaches. We present an ACL repair using FiberTape sutures as an internal brace and an adjustable cortical button fixation on the femur. ACL rupture is a condition in which restoration is essential to regaining adequate knee function. ACL repair may be indicated in patients with an acute tear (<4 weeks), Sherman classification type I or II tear, 35 years old or older, and with a mild-to-moderate activity level. ACL tightrope repair initially requires identification of the ACL tear. Following, there is femoral wall preparation and the creation of a drill tunnel in the femoral and tibial walls. FiberRing sutures are passed through the intact portion of the ACL as many times as desired. An ACL Tightrope is then fed through the FiberRing sutures. The ACL Tightrope and cortical button are passed through the femoral tunnel. FiberTape sutures are passed through a tibial tunnel to act as an internal brace. Range of motion and tension is assessed and adjusted as needed. Patients meeting indications for ACL repair and undergoing repair via Tightrope implants may have outcomes comparable to counterparts undergoing ACL reconstruction. Patient-completed functional knee scores, such as International Knee Documentation Committee (IKDC), Knee Injury and Osteoarthritis Outcome Score (KOOS), and Lysholm, are similar between the 2 restoration techniques. However, younger patients undergoing an ACL repair appear to have a higher failure rate compared with reconstruction. ACL repair can be an adjuvant treatment option with acute femoral sided tears. Caution should be exercised when performing this procedure on younger, higher level athletes. In our technique, use of adjustable cortical button minimizes bone loss on femoral wall while providing adequate fixation. The author(s) attests that consent has been obtained from any patient(s) appearing in this publication. If the individual may be identifiable, the author(s) has included a statement of release or other written form of approval from the patient(s) with this submission for publication.', metadata={'similarity_score': -0.053164295852184296, 'retrieval_method': 'knowledge_base_expansion'}, id='PMC11752394_gen_88')

Document(page_content='Snapping biceps femoris syndrome (SFS) represents a rare clinical entity in which the biceps femoris subluxates over the fibular head in deep flexion. Two primary pathophysiologies have been described including a prominent or abnormal fibular head morphology. Others have implicated an anomalous biceps femoris insertion. The diagnosis is made clinically, with operative and nonoperative intervention strategies available for treatment. SFS often results in audible snapping and associated pain at the lateral fibular head. When recalcitrant to nonoperative management, surgical intervention can lead to resolution of symptoms. We present the case of a college-aged male who has bilateral symptoms, worse on the right, which have resulted in significant activity modification and daily discomfort recalcitrant to anti-inflammatory medication and physical therapy. The patient was placed supine on the operating room table with an ipsilateral bump under the hip to assist in exposure of the lateral aspect of the knee. Examination under anesthesia (EUA) confirmed the snapping biceps femoris. A lateral approach to the knee and a common peroneal neurolysis was performed. The biceps femoris insertional anatomy was examined for anomalous tendon insertion or insertional tearing. The prominent fibular head was exposed and resected, with careful attention not to disrupt the lateral collateral ligament or popliteofibular ligament insertion sites. The biceps femoris was then repaired to the prepared bony bed of the fibula with one double-loaded suture anchor. Repeat EUA confirmed complete resolution of snapping even with maximal internal rotation of the tibia; this was carefully examined again with the tourniquet deflated to ensure its compressive effect was not partially responsible for the resolution. Published data pertaining to SFS is limited to case reports and small case series. With appropriate indications, surgical intervention yields promising results with a high percentage of patients returning to prior level of activity or prior participation level in sport. SFS can be diagnosed with a careful clinical assessment. When recalcitrant to nonoperative management, it is effectively treated with surgical intervention to restore normal fibular anatomy, and prevent recurrent instability and persistent pain. The presented technique allows for appropriate management of these rare injuries. The author(s) attests that consent has been obtained from any patient(s) appearing in this publication. If the individual may be identifiable, the author(s) has included a statement of release or other written form of approval from the patient(s) with this submission for publication.', metadata={'similarity_score': -0.053164295852184296, 'retrieval_method': 'knowledge_base_expansion'}, id='PMC11752538_gen_189')

Document(page_content='The medial ulnar collateral ligament (MUCL) is the primary restraint to valgus force on the elbow. Since the first description of MUCL reconstruction by Jobe et al in 1986, many technical advancements have been implemented to improve outcomes and reduce complications. The docking technique has emerged as one of the most commonly used techniques. Following repetitive stress on the elbow during the overhead throwing motion, the MUCL may become attenuated, insufficient, or rupture completely. Although nonoperative treatment with rest and therapy is often the initial treatment of choice, individuals who fail conservative measures may require MUCL reconstruction. The major steps of the procedure are (1) harvesting of palmaris longus autograft, (2) incision and exposure, (3) preparation of ulnar tunnel, (4) preparation of docking site on medial epicondyle, (5) graft passage, (6) graft tensioning and length determination, (7) final fixation, and (8) closure. This procedure allows for reconstruction of the MUCL, restoration of valgus stability to the elbow, and return to play rates of 80% to 95%. The docking technique has advantages over previously described MUCL reconstruction techniques in that it minimizes injury to the flexor pronator mass, avoids the ulnar nerve, allows for robust graft tensioning, and reduces the amount of bone removed from the medial epicondyle. The docking technique, as described in this video demonstration, is the most common MUCL reconstruction technique used today. When precise surgical steps are followed, complication rates are low and patient outcomes are favorable.', metadata={'similarity_score': -0.053164295852184296, 'retrieval_method': 'knowledge_base_expansion'}, id='PMC11752541_gen_188')

individual_results.query: How does SGLT2 inhibition affect kidney function?
individual_results.answer:
Based on the provided documents, there is no specific information regarding how SGLT2 inhibition affects kidney function. Document 1 discusses common treatments for type 2 diabetes, but does not mention SGLT2 inhibitors. Document 2 appears to mention genetic mutations in TP53 and TET2, which are not directly related to SGLT2 inhibition or kidney function. Document 3 and Document 4 do not provide any relevant information on this topic. Document 5 discusses pernicious anemia and hemolytic anemia, which are also not directly related to SGLT2 inhibition and kidney function.

Therefore, based on the information provided, it is uncertain how SGLT2 inhibition affects kidney function. Additional research and information from relevant sources would be needed to provide a comprehensive answer to this question.

individual_results.query: What is the mechanism of action of GLP-1 receptor agonists?
individual_results.answer:
GLP-1 receptor agonists, or glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor agonists, are a class of medications used in the treatment of type 2 diabetes. The mechanism of action of GLP-1 receptor agonists involves binding to and activating the GLP-1 receptor, which is found on various cells in the body including pancreatic beta cells. This activation leads to increased insulin secretion, decreased glucagon secretion, slowed gastric emptying, and increased satiety. These effects help to lower blood sugar levels, improve insulin sensitivity, and aid in weight loss.

However, based on the provided documents, there is no direct information on the mechanism of action of GLP-1 receptor agonists. Therefore, the information provided above is based on broader search results and general knowledge of the topic.

Document(page_content='Anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) restoration has been divided into repair versus reconstructive approaches. We present an ACL repair using FiberTape sutures as an internal brace and an adjustable cortical button fixation on the femur. ACL rupture is a condition in which restoration is essential to regaining adequate knee function. ACL repair may be indicated in patients with an acute tear (<4 weeks), Sherman classification type I or II tear, 35 years old or older, and with a mild-to-moderate activity level. ACL tightrope repair initially requires identification of the ACL tear. Following, there is femoral wall preparation and the creation of a drill tunnel in the femoral and tibial walls. FiberRing sutures are passed through the intact portion of the ACL as many times as desired. An ACL Tightrope is then fed through the FiberRing sutures. The ACL Tightrope and cortical button are passed through the femoral tunnel. FiberTape sutures are passed through a tibial tunnel to act as an internal brace. Range of motion and tension is assessed and adjusted as needed. Patients meeting indications for ACL repair and undergoing repair via Tightrope implants may have outcomes comparable to counterparts undergoing ACL reconstruction. Patient-completed functional knee scores, such as International Knee Documentation Committee (IKDC), Knee Injury and Osteoarthritis Outcome Score (KOOS), and Lysholm, are similar between the 2 restoration techniques. However, younger patients undergoing an ACL repair appear to have a higher failure rate compared with reconstruction. ACL repair can be an adjuvant treatment option with acute femoral sided tears. Caution should be exercised when performing this procedure on younger, higher level athletes. In our technique, use of adjustable cortical button minimizes bone loss on femoral wall while providing adequate fixation. The author(s) attests that consent has been obtained from any patient(s) appearing in this publication. If the individual may be identifiable, the author(s) has included a statement of release or other written form of approval from the patient(s) with this submission for publication.', metadata={'similarity_score': -0.04979115352034569, 'retrieval_method': 'knowledge_base_expansion'}, id='PMC11752394_gen_88')

Document(page_content='Snapping biceps femoris syndrome (SFS) represents a rare clinical entity in which the biceps femoris subluxates over the fibular head in deep flexion. Two primary pathophysiologies have been described including a prominent or abnormal fibular head morphology. Others have implicated an anomalous biceps femoris insertion. The diagnosis is made clinically, with operative and nonoperative intervention strategies available for treatment. SFS often results in audible snapping and associated pain at the lateral fibular head. When recalcitrant to nonoperative management, surgical intervention can lead to resolution of symptoms. We present the case of a college-aged male who has bilateral symptoms, worse on the right, which have resulted in significant activity modification and daily discomfort recalcitrant to anti-inflammatory medication and physical therapy. The patient was placed supine on the operating room table with an ipsilateral bump under the hip to assist in exposure of the lateral aspect of the knee. Examination under anesthesia (EUA) confirmed the snapping biceps femoris. A lateral approach to the knee and a common peroneal neurolysis was performed. The biceps femoris insertional anatomy was examined for anomalous tendon insertion or insertional tearing. The prominent fibular head was exposed and resected, with careful attention not to disrupt the lateral collateral ligament or popliteofibular ligament insertion sites. The biceps femoris was then repaired to the prepared bony bed of the fibula with one double-loaded suture anchor. Repeat EUA confirmed complete resolution of snapping even with maximal internal rotation of the tibia; this was carefully examined again with the tourniquet deflated to ensure its compressive effect was not partially responsible for the resolution. Published data pertaining to SFS is limited to case reports and small case series. With appropriate indications, surgical intervention yields promising results with a high percentage of patients returning to prior level of activity or prior participation level in sport. SFS can be diagnosed with a careful clinical assessment. When recalcitrant to nonoperative management, it is effectively treated with surgical intervention to restore normal fibular anatomy, and prevent recurrent instability and persistent pain. The presented technique allows for appropriate management of these rare injuries. The author(s) attests that consent has been obtained from any patient(s) appearing in this publication. If the individual may be identifiable, the author(s) has included a statement of release or other written form of approval from the patient(s) with this submission for publication.', metadata={'similarity_score': -0.04979115352034569, 'retrieval_method': 'knowledge_base_expansion'}, id='PMC11752538_gen_189')

Document(page_content='The medial ulnar collateral ligament (MUCL) is the primary restraint to valgus force on the elbow. Since the first description of MUCL reconstruction by Jobe et al in 1986, many technical advancements have been implemented to improve outcomes and reduce complications. The docking technique has emerged as one of the most commonly used techniques. Following repetitive stress on the elbow during the overhead throwing motion, the MUCL may become attenuated, insufficient, or rupture completely. Although nonoperative treatment with rest and therapy is often the initial treatment of choice, individuals who fail conservative measures may require MUCL reconstruction. The major steps of the procedure are (1) harvesting of palmaris longus autograft, (2) incision and exposure, (3) preparation of ulnar tunnel, (4) preparation of docking site on medial epicondyle, (5) graft passage, (6) graft tensioning and length determination, (7) final fixation, and (8) closure. This procedure allows for reconstruction of the MUCL, restoration of valgus stability to the elbow, and return to play rates of 80% to 95%. The docking technique has advantages over previously described MUCL reconstruction techniques in that it minimizes injury to the flexor pronator mass, avoids the ulnar nerve, allows for robust graft tensioning, and reduces the amount of bone removed from the medial epicondyle. The docking technique, as described in this video demonstration, is the most common MUCL reconstruction technique used today. When precise surgical steps are followed, complication rates are low and patient outcomes are favorable.', metadata={'similarity_score': -0.04979115352034569, 'retrieval_method': 'knowledge_base_expansion'}, id='PMC11752541_gen_188')

individual_results.answer:

Document 2 does not provide relevant information to answer the question. Document 4 discusses the translation and evaluation of a physical assessment tool in Brazil, which is not relevant to the question. Document 5 discusses pernicious anemia and hemolytic anemia, which are not related to the cardiovascular benefits of SGLT2 inhibitors.

Therefore, based on the provided documents, it is uncertain and incomplete to determine the cardiovascular benefits of SGLT2 inhibitors. Additional research or documents specifically focused on this topic would be needed to provide a comprehensive answer.

Document(page_content='To translate, cross-culturally adapt and evaluate the clinimetric properties of the Chelsea Critical Care Physical Assessment for the functional evaluation of patients admitted to intensive care units in Brazil. The steps involved in the translation and cross-cultural adaptation of the instrument included the following: initial translation, synthesis, back-translation, review by an expert committee and pretesting. Intra- and interrater reliability and agreement were analyzed with data generated from physical therapists’ assessments of the same group of patients with the translated and adapted instrument (n = 30). The evaluations were performed by two physical therapists who independently and blindly obtained scores from the patients. Qualitative analysis was performed by the review committee with the expert-adapted and expert-synthesized translation of the Chelsea Critical Care Physical Assessment scale into Portuguese, and the content validity index was calculated. Agreement was achieved between the translations of the Chelsea Critical Care Physical Assessment scale into Brazilian. Conceptual, idiomatic, semantic and experimental equivalences between the original and translated versions were obtained, resulting in the Brazilian version of the instrument, called the\n Avaliação Física em Cuidados Intensivos Chelsea A version of the Chelsea Critical Care Physical Assessment scale can be reliably used in Brazil for functional assessment following its translation and cross-cultural adaptation to Brazilian Portuguese and shows evidence of excellent interrater reliability.', metadata={'similarity_score': -0.07223846763372421, 'retrieval_method': 'knowledge_base_expansion'}, id='PMC11750119_gen_7')

Document(page_content='Pernicious anemia\xa0is an autoimmune disease characterized by vitamin B12 deficiency due to antibodies that target intrinsic factor and/or parietal cells in the stomach. Hemolytic anemia is rarely seen in vitamin B12 deficiency. This case report highlights a patient with a history of autoimmune thyroid disease who presented with severe hemolytic anemia and vitamin B12 deficiency from pernicious anemia. This report discusses the association of hemolytic anemia with vitamin B12 deficiency, the association of pernicious anemia with other autoimmune diseases, and the treatment of pernicious anemia.', metadata={'similarity_score': -0.07223846763372421, 'retrieval_method': 'knowledge_base_expansion'}, id='PMC11755207_gen_92')

Document(page_content='To identify the occurrence of the amniotic deformity adhesions, mutilation (ADAM) complex and imperative role of fetal autopsy in diagnosing this condition. A retrospective descriptive study spanning nine years, from January 2014 to January 2022, was conducted at the Department of Pathology within a tertiary care hospital in South India. The study focused on analyzing the clinical presentation, prenatal ultrasonogram, and morphological features of fetuses with the ADAM complex, limb body wall complex, or amniotic bands. Among the 438 fetuses assessed during the study period, five fetuses showed features of the ADAM complex (0.01%). The most frequent gestational age observed was 12–18 weeks and most fetuses were female. The common anomaly encountered was limb defects, followed by abdominal and cranial anomalies. The diagnosis of the ADAM complex relies primarily on fetal autopsy to differentiate it from similar conditions like anencephaly or body-stalk anomalies. The pathologist plays a crucial role in understanding the complexities of the ADAM complex. Advanced antenatal imaging and therapies offer potential for prevention through improved counseling.', metadata={'similarity_score': -0.07223846763372421, 'retrieval_method': 'knowledge_base_expansion'}, id='PMC11755208_gen_24')

Document(page_content='Hip arthroscopy is technically demanding with a steep learning curve, and labral repair is an important component of the surgical treatment of femoroacetabular impingement (FAI) syndrome. As hip arthroscopy indications and techniques are evolving, it is important to remain focused on teaching techniques that are easily mastered and have a measurable benefit to patient outcomes. Patients with FAI syndrome and labral tear who have failed conservative treatment may benefit from hip arthroscopy, labral repair, and femoroplasty. Labral repair is an essential component of the surgical treatment of FAI syndrome. The hip is accessed in standard fashion, and multiple knotless anchors are used for labral repair. Repair sutures are passed around the labrum in an inverted fashion. This inversion technique ensures the labrum is not everted away from the acetabular rim and that the final position of the labrum will restore a good suction seal on the femoral head. Femoroplasty and capsule closure are always performed. Patients can reliably expect improvements in hip pain and function. A cohort of 62 patients was investigated, and these patients demonstrated significant improvement in multiple patient-reported outcomes related to physical function, activity, and pain at 2 years after hip arthroscopy. Forty-seven percent stated they felt “completely better” at 2 years postoperatively. Good hip arthroscopy technique in the proper patient can yield excellent results. The inversion labral repair technique reliably restores the suction seal and prevents eversion of the labrum to preserve normal function. The author(s) attests that consent has been obtained from any patient(s) appearing in this publication. If the individual may be identifiable, the author(s) has included a statement of release or other written form of approval from the patient(s) with this submission for publication.', metadata={'similarity_score': -0.07223846763372421, 'retrieval_method': 'knowledge_base_expansion'}, id='PMC11752188_gen_92')

individual_results.query: What is the role of ACE inhibitors in heart failure?
individual_results.answer: Based on the provided documents, there is no specific information regarding the role of ACE inhibitors in heart failure. The documents primarily discuss topics such as type 2 diabetes treatments, mutations in genes like TP53 and TET2, translation and adaptation of assessment tools, and autoimmune diseases like pernicious anemia. Therefore, the role of ACE inhibitors in heart failure cannot be determined based on the information provided in these documents. Further research or consultation with medical professionals specializing in cardiology would be necessary to accurately answer this question.

Document(page_content='To translate, cross-culturally adapt and evaluate the clinimetric properties of the Chelsea Critical Care Physical Assessment for the functional evaluation of patients admitted to intensive care units in Brazil. The steps involved in the translation and cross-cultural adaptation of the instrument included the following: initial translation, synthesis, back-translation, review by an expert committee and pretesting. Intra- and interrater reliability and agreement were analyzed with data generated from physical therapists’ assessments of the same group of patients with the translated and adapted instrument (n = 30). The evaluations were performed by two physical therapists who independently and blindly obtained scores from the patients. Qualitative analysis was performed by the review committee with the expert-adapted and expert-synthesized translation of the Chelsea Critical Care Physical Assessment scale into Portuguese, and the content validity index was calculated. Agreement was achieved between the translations of the Chelsea Critical Care Physical Assessment scale into Brazilian. Conceptual, idiomatic, semantic and experimental equivalences between the original and translated versions were obtained, resulting in the Brazilian version of the instrument, called the\n Avaliação Física em Cuidados Intensivos Chelsea A version of the Chelsea Critical Care Physical Assessment scale can be reliably used in Brazil for functional assessment following its translation and cross-cultural adaptation to Brazilian Portuguese and shows evidence of excellent interrater reliability.', metadata={'similarity_score': -0.039040956646203995, 'retrieval_method': 'knowledge_base_expansion'}, id='PMC11750119_gen_7')

Document(page_content='Pernicious anemia\xa0is an autoimmune disease characterized by vitamin B12 deficiency due to antibodies that target intrinsic factor and/or parietal cells in the stomach. Hemolytic anemia is rarely seen in vitamin B12 deficiency. This case report highlights a patient with a history of autoimmune thyroid disease who presented with severe hemolytic anemia and vitamin B12 deficiency from pernicious anemia. This report discusses the association of hemolytic anemia with vitamin B12 deficiency, the association of pernicious anemia with other autoimmune diseases, and the treatment of pernicious anemia.', metadata={'similarity_score': -0.039040956646203995, 'retrieval_method': 'knowledge_base_expansion'}, id='PMC11755207_gen_92')

Document(page_content='To identify the occurrence of the amniotic deformity adhesions, mutilation (ADAM) complex and imperative role of fetal autopsy in diagnosing this condition. A retrospective descriptive study spanning nine years, from January 2014 to January 2022, was conducted at the Department of Pathology within a tertiary care hospital in South India. The study focused on analyzing the clinical presentation, prenatal ultrasonogram, and morphological features of fetuses with the ADAM complex, limb body wall complex, or amniotic bands. Among the 438 fetuses assessed during the study period, five fetuses showed features of the ADAM complex (0.01%). The most frequent gestational age observed was 12–18 weeks and most fetuses were female. The common anomaly encountered was limb defects, followed by abdominal and cranial anomalies. The diagnosis of the ADAM complex relies primarily on fetal autopsy to differentiate it from similar conditions like anencephaly or body-stalk anomalies. The pathologist plays a crucial role in understanding the complexities of the ADAM complex. Advanced antenatal imaging and therapies offer potential for prevention through improved counseling.', metadata={'similarity_score': -0.039040956646203995, 'retrieval_method': 'knowledge_base_expansion'}, id='PMC11755208_gen_24')

Document(page_content='Hip arthroscopy is technically demanding with a steep learning curve, and labral repair is an important component of the surgical treatment of femoroacetabular impingement (FAI) syndrome. As hip arthroscopy indications and techniques are evolving, it is important to remain focused on teaching techniques that are easily mastered and have a measurable benefit to patient outcomes. Patients with FAI syndrome and labral tear who have failed conservative treatment may benefit from hip arthroscopy, labral repair, and femoroplasty. Labral repair is an essential component of the surgical treatment of FAI syndrome. The hip is accessed in standard fashion, and multiple knotless anchors are used for labral repair. Repair sutures are passed around the labrum in an inverted fashion. This inversion technique ensures the labrum is not everted away from the acetabular rim and that the final position of the labrum will restore a good suction seal on the femoral head. Femoroplasty and capsule closure are always performed. Patients can reliably expect improvements in hip pain and function. A cohort of 62 patients was investigated, and these patients demonstrated significant improvement in multiple patient-reported outcomes related to physical function, activity, and pain at 2 years after hip arthroscopy. Forty-seven percent stated they felt “completely better” at 2 years postoperatively. Good hip arthroscopy technique in the proper patient can yield excellent results. The inversion labral repair technique reliably restores the suction seal and prevents eversion of the labrum to preserve normal function. The author(s) attests that consent has been obtained from any patient(s) appearing in this publication. If the individual may be identifiable, the author(s) has included a statement of release or other written form of approval from the patient(s) with this submission for publication.', metadata={'similarity_score': -0.039040956646203995, 'retrieval_method': 'knowledge_base_expansion'}, id='PMC11752188_gen_92')

Document(page_content='Anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) restoration has been divided into repair versus reconstructive approaches. We present an ACL repair using FiberTape sutures as an internal brace and an adjustable cortical button fixation on the femur. ACL rupture is a condition in which restoration is essential to regaining adequate knee function. ACL repair may be indicated in patients with an acute tear (<4 weeks), Sherman classification type I or II tear, 35 years old or older, and with a mild-to-moderate activity level. ACL tightrope repair initially requires identification of the ACL tear. Following, there is femoral wall preparation and the creation of a drill tunnel in the femoral and tibial walls. FiberRing sutures are passed through the intact portion of the ACL as many times as desired. An ACL Tightrope is then fed through the FiberRing sutures. The ACL Tightrope and cortical button are passed through the femoral tunnel. FiberTape sutures are passed through a tibial tunnel to act as an internal brace. Range of motion and tension is assessed and adjusted as needed. Patients meeting indications for ACL repair and undergoing repair via Tightrope implants may have outcomes comparable to counterparts undergoing ACL reconstruction. Patient-completed functional knee scores, such as International Knee Documentation Committee (IKDC), Knee Injury and Osteoarthritis Outcome Score (KOOS), and Lysholm, are similar between the 2 restoration techniques. However, younger patients undergoing an ACL repair appear to have a higher failure rate compared with reconstruction. ACL repair can be an adjuvant treatment option with acute femoral sided tears. Caution should be exercised when performing this procedure on younger, higher level athletes. In our technique, use of adjustable cortical button minimizes bone loss on femoral wall while providing adequate fixation. The author(s) attests that consent has been obtained from any patient(s) appearing in this publication. If the individual may be identifiable, the author(s) has included a statement of release or other written form of approval from the patient(s) with this submission for publication.', metadata={'similarity_score': -0.039040956646203995, 'retrieval_method': 'knowledge_base_expansion'}, id='PMC11752394_gen_88')

Document(page_content='Snapping biceps femoris syndrome (SFS) represents a rare clinical entity in which the biceps femoris subluxates over the fibular head in deep flexion. Two primary pathophysiologies have been described including a prominent or abnormal fibular head morphology. Others have implicated an anomalous biceps femoris insertion. The diagnosis is made clinically, with operative and nonoperative intervention strategies available for treatment. SFS often results in audible snapping and associated pain at the lateral fibular head. When recalcitrant to nonoperative management, surgical intervention can lead to resolution of symptoms. We present the case of a college-aged male who has bilateral symptoms, worse on the right, which have resulted in significant activity modification and daily discomfort recalcitrant to anti-inflammatory medication and physical therapy. The patient was placed supine on the operating room table with an ipsilateral bump under the hip to assist in exposure of the lateral aspect of the knee. Examination under anesthesia (EUA) confirmed the snapping biceps femoris. A lateral approach to the knee and a common peroneal neurolysis was performed. The biceps femoris insertional anatomy was examined for anomalous tendon insertion or insertional tearing. The prominent fibular head was exposed and resected, with careful attention not to disrupt the lateral collateral ligament or popliteofibular ligament insertion sites. The biceps femoris was then repaired to the prepared bony bed of the fibula with one double-loaded suture anchor. Repeat EUA confirmed complete resolution of snapping even with maximal internal rotation of the tibia; this was carefully examined again with the tourniquet deflated to ensure its compressive effect was not partially responsible for the resolution. Published data pertaining to SFS is limited to case reports and small case series. With appropriate indications, surgical intervention yields promising results with a high percentage of patients returning to prior level of activity or prior participation level in sport. SFS can be diagnosed with a careful clinical assessment. When recalcitrant to nonoperative management, it is effectively treated with surgical intervention to restore normal fibular anatomy, and prevent recurrent instability and persistent pain. The presented technique allows for appropriate management of these rare injuries. The author(s) attests that consent has been obtained from any patient(s) appearing in this publication. If the individual may be identifiable, the author(s) has included a statement of release or other written form of approval from the patient(s) with this submission for publication.', metadata={'similarity_score': -0.039040956646203995, 'retrieval_method': 'knowledge_base_expansion'}, id='PMC11752538_gen_189')

Document(page_content='The medial ulnar collateral ligament (MUCL) is the primary restraint to valgus force on the elbow. Since the first description of MUCL reconstruction by Jobe et al in 1986, many technical advancements have been implemented to improve outcomes and reduce complications. The docking technique has emerged as one of the most commonly used techniques. Following repetitive stress on the elbow during the overhead throwing motion, the MUCL may become attenuated, insufficient, or rupture completely. Although nonoperative treatment with rest and therapy is often the initial treatment of choice, individuals who fail conservative measures may require MUCL reconstruction. The major steps of the procedure are (1) harvesting of palmaris longus autograft, (2) incision and exposure, (3) preparation of ulnar tunnel, (4) preparation of docking site on medial epicondyle, (5) graft passage, (6) graft tensioning and length determination, (7) final fixation, and (8) closure. This procedure allows for reconstruction of the MUCL, restoration of valgus stability to the elbow, and return to play rates of 80% to 95%. The docking technique has advantages over previously described MUCL reconstruction techniques in that it minimizes injury to the flexor pronator mass, avoids the ulnar nerve, allows for robust graft tensioning, and reduces the amount of bone removed from the medial epicondyle. The docking technique, as described in this video demonstration, is the most common MUCL reconstruction technique used today. When precise surgical steps are followed, complication rates are low and patient outcomes are favorable.', metadata={'similarity_score': -0.039040956646203995, 'retrieval_method': 'knowledge_base_expansion'}, id='PMC11752541_gen_188')
individual_results.ground_truth: ACE inhibitors treat heart failure by blocking the conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II, which reduces vasoconstriction and aldosterone production, decreases afterload and preload, improves cardiac output, and ultimately reduces mortality and hospitalizations in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction.

individual_results.query: How do glucocorticoids suppress inflammation?
individual_results.answer:
Glucocorticoids suppress inflammation by inhibiting the production of inflammatory cytokines and prostaglandins, reducing the migration of inflammatory cells to the site of inflammation, and suppressing the activity of immune cells involved in the inflammatory response. Glucocorticoids achieve this by binding to glucocorticoid receptors in the cytoplasm of target cells, leading to the activation of anti-inflammatory genes and the repression of pro-inflammatory genes. This results in decreased inflammation and the resolution of the inflammatory process.

Unfortunately, the provided documents do not contain specific information related to how glucocorticoids suppress inflammation. Therefore, the answer is based on broader knowledge of the topic.
